document.masterDocTitle: The cicadas (Hemiptera: Cicadidae) of Bolivia including the descriptions of fifteen new species, the resurrection of one genus and two species, seven new combinations, six new synonymies, and twenty-eight new records

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The cicadas (Hemiptera: Cicadidae) of Bolivia including the descriptions of fifteen new species, the resurrection of one genus and two species, seven new combinations, six new synonymies, and twenty-eight new records

bibRefCitation.author: Sanborn, A. F. & Heath, M. S.
bibRefCitation.refString: Sanborn, A. F. & Heath, M. S. (2014) The cicadas of Argentina with new records, a new genus and fifteen new species (Hemiptera: Cicadoidea: Cicadidae). Zootaxa, 3883 (1), 1 - 94. https: // doi. org / 10.11646 / zootaxa. 3883.1. 1

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Dorisiana metcalfi Sanborn & Heath 2014
nom. nov. pro
Cicada viridis Olivier, 1790
nec
Cicada viridis
Linnaeus, 1758: 60
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
REMARKS. Metcalf (1952) previously synonymized the species with
Dorisiana semilata ( Walker, 1850 )
. However, the taxon represented by
Cicada viridis Olivier, 1790
appears to be distinct from
D. semilata
in genitalia and other morphological characteristics so that Sanborn & Heath (2014) provided
Dorisiana metcalfi
as a replacement name for the taxon represented by
Cicada viridis Olivier, 1790
. Specimens from Suriname are required to be able to determine if
D. metcalfi
and
D. semilata
are in fact synonyms.

The most similar Bolivian species is
D. noriegai Sanborn & Heath, 2014
. This species can be distinguished by the lack of piceous spots on the posterior head and posterior eye, the lack of marks on the parapsidal suture, the curved ventral margin to the timbal cover, the straight posterior opercular margin, the piceous pile on the abdominal tergites, the longer pygofer basal lobes, the extensions of the lateral branch of the uncus are short rather than horn-like, the female dorsal beak not extending beyond the anal styles, and the ovipositor not extending beyond the dorsal beak.

MATERIAL EXAMINED .
